habitat_description:
In General:
Breeding habitat for the black tern consists of shallow freshwater marshes with emergent vegettation (Heath et al. 2009). This may include prairie sloughts, lake/river/island margins, impoundments, and wet meadows (Heath et al. 2009; NatureServe 2009). Most nests are found in semipermanent ponds (Heath et al. 2009).
This species can be found up to 1540 meters in elevation. Breeding habitat is generally found in landscapes with high wetland density; this species prefers marshes/complexes of >20 ha. However, nests have been reported in wetlands as small as 5.3 ha (Brown and Dinsmore, 1986). Black terns are less likely to be found in wetlands surrounded by woody vegetation (Heath et al. 2009).
